title-group.article-title: Thermoplastic natural rubber based on polyamide-12 blended with various types of natural rubber
title-group.subtitle: Effect of processing oils and plasticizer

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Rubber Technology and Polymer Science, Center of Excellence in Natural Rubber Technology, Prince of Songkla University, Pattani, Thailand
2Department of Polymer Engineering, Faculty of Engineering and Computer Science, University of Applied Sciences, Osnabrück, Germany

author-notes.corresp: Charoen Nakason, Center of Excellence in Natural Rubber Technology, Faculty of Science and Technology, Prince of Songkla University, Pattani, 94000, Thailand Email: ncharoen@bunga.pn.psu.ac.th

abstract.p: Thermoplastic natural rubber (NR) of dynamically cured 60/40 NR/polyamide (PA) blends has been prepared by using three types of NR: unmodified air dried sheet NR, epoxidized NR (ENR) with 25 and 50 mol% epoxides. Plasticizer (i.e. dioctyl phthalate (DOP)) and processing oils (i.e. treated distillate aromatic extract and paraffinic oils) were incorporated in the blends. Stress relaxation, rheological, mechanical, and thermal properties of the blends were investigated. It was found that mixing torque, shear viscosity, tensile strength, and hardness of the oil-extended blends exhibited lower values compared with the blends without oil. But higher elongation was observed due to the distribution of oil into PA-12 and rubber phases. Furthermore, an increasing trend of stress relaxation behavior and rubber index was observed in the blends with DOP, which revealed an improvement in elastic properties. It was also found that the incorporation of DOP caused an enhancement in thermal behavior in terms of T 10, T 50, T 90, and integral values, but a reduction in the glass transition temperature (T g) of NR phase and crystallization temperature (T c) of PA-12 matrix was also observed. This is attributed to the similar solubility parameter of DOP compared with the blend components. It was also found that the dynamically cured blends showed smaller rubber domains dispersed in PA-12 matrix. However, the addition of DOP resulted in an increase in the size of vulcanized rubber particles.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer blend is one of the intense fields of research to enhance the useful properties of polymers. 1 Thermoplastic elastomers (TPEs) are the materials based on the blending of thermoplastic and rubber, which enhance the processing characteristics and the rubber elasticity. 2 If the rubber component is vulcanized during mixing operation at high temperature (i.e. dynamic vulcanization), the micron-sized vulcanized rubber particles are finely dispersed in a thermoplastic matrix. This material is classified as thermoplastic vulcanizate or dynamic vulcanizate. 3,4 TPE, based on the blending of natural rubber (NR) and thermoplastic, is typically classified as thermoplastic NRs (TPNRs). 5 Apart from blending of unmodified NR with nonpolar thermoplastic, 6,7 chemically modified NR has been used to prepare the TPNRs by blending with polar thermoplastics. The main objective of modifying NR molecules is to enhance blend compatibility with polar thermoplastic and to improve some useful properties, such as oil and heat resistant, gas permeability, and aging properties. The most frequently used modified NR is epoxidized NR (ENR). 8,9

Blending of polyamide (PA) and rubber has been investigated by focusing on the improvement of impact properties of PAs. These include blending of PA-6 with various types of rubbers, such as ethylene propylene diene monomers (EPDM), 2 acrylate rubber (ACM), 10 acrylonitrile butadiene rubber (NBR), 11 epichlorohydrin rubber, 12 and NR. 13 Furthermore, other types of PA/rubber blends include PA-11/NBR, 14 PA-6/PA-6,6/PA-1010 copolymer/EPDM, 15 PA-6/PA-6,6/PA-1010 copolymer/NBR, 16 and ENR/PA-12 blends. 5,17 Most of these works are related to the blending of high melting temperature PAs with high heat resistant rubbers. However, less information is available on the blending of NR and PAs due to poor heat resistance property of NR. 5 Thus, we have selected PA-12 with low melting temperature at approximately 178°C to blend with NR and ENR. The main aim of this work was to improve mechanical properties and oil resistance and also to ease the processing of NR.

Both processing oil and plasticizer have been typically incorporated into TPEs in order to improve the processability and to enhance elastomeric performance. 18 Addition of processing oil and plasticizer causes lowering of the cohesive forces between the polymer chains and hence increasing the chain mobility. This causes an improvement in deformability and flexibility of blends at low temperatures. 19 This is because the oil is generally believed to be predominantly absorbed by the rubber phase in the rubber state (i.e. in solid state), 20 with some part of oil resides in the amorphous region of the thermoplastic phase, which leads to an improvement in elasticity of the blends. 21 During deformation in solid state, the rubber particles and the thermoplastic layers surrounding the particles behave elastically. 22,23 In the molten state, the oil is distributed into both the phases and improves the processability. 19,24 Influence of various processing oils has been previously investigated in dynamically cured NR/polypropylene (PP), 18 EPDM/PP, 24 ENR/HDPE, 25 PP/EPDM, and PP/SEBS blends. 26 In the NR/PP blends, it was found that an increase in the amount of paraffinic oil (PO) to a certain level caused saturation of oil in the thermoplastic (PP) phase and then the excess amount of oil diffuses into NR phase resulting in larger swollen vulcanized rubber domains. 18 Furthermore, the remaining excess amount of oil was separated as submicron pools distributed in the PP matrix, as a third phase of the blend. This caused lowering glass transition temperature (T g) of rubber and PP phases, crystalline melting temperature (T m), degree of crystallinity of PP, and strength of the material. 18 Ester-type plasticizers have also been incorporated to improve the elastomeric properties at low temperature (i.e. lowering T g) in dynamically cured EPDM/PP blends. 21 Also, the influence of plasticizer in ACM/PA-6 blends was investigated and found to be decreased in T g of ACM, while the PA-6 phase was unaffected in the presence of dioctyl phthalate (DOP) and dibutyl phthalate. 10

The main objective of the current study was to investigate the effect of two different types of processing oils (i.e. PO and treated distillate aromatic extract (TDAE) oil) and plasticizer (i.e. DOP) on the properties of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends. Mixing behavior, curing characteristics, stress relaxation, as well as rheological, mechanical, and thermal properties of the oil extended dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends were studied. Furthermore, evolution of T g, T m, and degree of crystallinity of the PA phase was also investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Three different types of NRs used in this study were unmodified NR in the form of an air dried sheet (ADS; Khuan Pan Tae Farmer Cooperation, Phattalung, Thailand) and ENRs with two different levels of epoxide groups at 25 mol% (ENR-25) and 50 mol% (ENR-50; Muangmaiguthrie Co. Ltd, Phuket, Thailand). The Moony viscosities (ML1 + 4 (100°C)) of ADS, ENR-25, and ENR-50 are 101, 81, and 70, respectively. Nonreinforced injection molding grade PA-12 (Grilamid L20G) was used as thermoplastic blending component (EMS-Grivory GmbH, Gross-Umstadt, Germany). The melting temperature and melt flow index (MFI) of the PA-12 are 178°C and 125 g/10 min (5 kg, 275°C), respectively. The Peroxan BIB-40 MB [(1,3/1,4)-phenylene-bis(1-methylethylidene)]bis[tert-butyl] peroxide on calcium carbonate carrier, with the active peroxide content of 40 wt% was used as vulcanizing agent (Pergan GmbH, Bocholt, Germany). The triallyl cyanurate (Rhenogran TAC-50) with the active agent of 50 wt% was used as a coagent (Rhein Chemie Rheinau GmbH, Mannheim, Germany). The zinc oxide was manufactured by Lanxess (Leverkusen, Germany). The stearic acid was manufactured by Unichema International B.V. (Gauda, The Netherlannds). The polyphenolic antioxidant (Wingstay-L) was manufactured by Eliokem Inc. (Ohio, USA). Two types of processing oils were used: TDAE oil (VivaTec 500, Hansen & Rosenthal KG (H&R Group), Hamburg, Germany) and free aromatic PO (Shell Ondina 941, Shell, Hamburg, Germany). Also, DOP (Vestinol AH plasticizer) was manufactured by A+E Fischer Chemie GmbH & Co. KG (Wiesbaden, Germany). Commercial diesel fuel oil and engine oil were used as testing liquids for solvent resistant properties of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends.

sec.title: Preparation of rubber compounds
sec.p: Oil extended rubber compounds were prepared by mixing rubbers (i.e. ADS, ENR-25, and ENR-50) with vulcanizing agent and processing oils using Brabender Measuring Mixers type 350E equipped with Plasti-Corder Lab-Station (Brabender GmbH & Co. KG, Germany) at 80°C, with a rotor speed of 40 r/min and a fill factor of 75% for 12–14 min, as the formulations shown in Table 1. The rubber was first masticated for 1 min (ENR-25 or ENR-50) or 3 min (ADS). Vulcanizing agents were then incorporated step-by-step into the mixing chamber, as described in Table 2. Three different types of plasticizers and processing oils (i.e. DOP, TDAE oil, and PO) with a loading level of 30 phr were each incorporated into the blends, as formulations and the step of compounding shown in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. The rubber compound was eventually dumped from the mixing chamber and cooled down to room temperature. The rubber compounds without oils and plasticizer were also prepared for a comparison purpose.

caption.p: Compounding formulations of various types of rubbers without and with 30 phr of processing oils or plasticizer

fn.p: DOP, dioctyl phthalate; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PO, paraffinic oil.

caption.p: Steps of adding chemicals and processing oil or plasticizer into the mixing chamber

tr.td: 30 phr of processing oil or plasticizer

fn.p: ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber.

sec.title: Curing properties
sec.p: It is important to understand curing behavior of rubber before dynamic vulcanization during blending with thermoplastic. Therefore, curing characteristics of ADS, ENR-25, and ENR-50 compounds without and with 30 phr of processing oil or plasticizer were tested using D-MDR 3000 (MonTech Werkstoffprüfmaschinen GmbH, Germany) with and angle of 0.5°/1.67 Hz/190°C for 35 min.

sec.title: Preparation of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends
sec.p: PA-12 was first dried in hot air oven at 40°C for 24 h. The dynamically cured 60/40 NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of oil or plasticizer were prepared using Haake Rheocord 600 laboratory internal mixer (Thermo Electron Corporation, Karlsruhe, Germany). Blending was performed by first incorporating the rubber compound into the mixing chamber at 160°C, with a rotor speed of 80 r/min and a fill factor of 75% for 1 min before increasing the rotor speed to 150 r/min for another 1 min. The PA-12 component was then incorporated after the temperature was raised to approximately 170°C. The temperature of the material was thereafter raised to approximately 190–210°C due to the frictional heat and dynamic vulcanization. The rotor speed was then decreased to 60 r/min and continued mixing for another 10 min with the total mixing time of 12 min. The blend product was dumped from the mixer, cooled down to room temperature, and pelletized for a further fabrication and characterization processes.

sec.title: Tensile and hardness tests
sec.p: The pellets of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of oil or plasticizer were fabricated into dumbbell shaped specimens (ISO 527 type 5A) using Babyplast 6/10P-T micromolding machine with 12 mm piston diameter (Cronoplast, S.L. Barcelona, Spain). Then, tensile test was performed using the dumbbell specimens at 23 ± 2°C according to ISO 527 using a Zwick Z 1545 tensile testing machine (Zwick GmbH & Co. KG, Ulm, Germany) with the extension speed of 200 mm/min. Indentation hardness was also tested by durometer Shore D according to ISO 868 using a hardness testing machine (Karl Frank GmbH, Weinheim, Germany).

sec.title: Rheological properties
sec.p: Shear flow properties of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of oils or plasticizer were characterized using high pressure capillary rheometer (Göttfert Rheo-Tester 2000, Göttfert Werkstoff-Prüfmaschinen GmbH, Buchen, Germany). The test was carried out using a wide range of shear rates (10–2000 s−1) at 230°C. Dimensions of the capillary die used were 1 mm diameter, 20 mm length, and 180° entry angle with an aspect ratio (L/D) of 20/1. The material was first incorporated into the rheometer’s barrel and purged until reaching the pressure at approximately 100 MPa to eliminate bubbles and get a compact mass in the barrel. The pressure was then dropped to approximately 10 MPa. The material was thereafter preconditioned in the barrel for at least 5 min. The test was then carried out with a set of shear rates in a program via microprocessor. During the test, pressure drop across the capillary channel and melt temperature were captured via a data acquisition systems. The apparent values of shear stress, shear rate, and shear viscosity were calculated using a derivative of the Poiseuille law for capillary flow, as described elsewhere. 27

sec.title: Temperature scanning stress relaxation
sec.p:
The temperature scanning stress relaxation (TSSR) measurement of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends was performed using TSSR instrument (Brabender GmbH, Duisburg, Germany) with a constant tensile strain of 25%. The dumbbell test piece (i.e. type 5A, ISO527) was first strained and preconditioned at 23°C for 2 h to allow the short time relaxation processes and to reach a quasi-equilibrium state. The sample was then heated with a constant heating rate of 2 K/min until the stress relaxation has been completed or the rupture of the sample has occurred. The force–temperature curves with certain characteristics such as T 10, T 50, T 90, and the rubber index (RI) were characterized. It is noted that the temperature T x stands for the temperature at which the force (F) has decreased × percentage with respect to the initial force (F 0). The RI is a measurement of the rubber-like behavior of the material, which was calculated based on the area underneath the force–temperature curves, as shown below 28,29 : 1
R I

where F(T) is the force at testing temperature T and F 0 is the initial force at a starting temperature (T 0). The temperature T 90 is the temperature at which the force F has decreased to about 90% with respect to the initial force (F 0).

In addition, the stress relaxation behavior at the elevated temperatures is of major interest with respect to the application properties of TPEs. Therefore, the relaxation spectrum, H′(T), was calculated using the following equation 28 : 2

where σ(T) is the temperature dependent stress and ∊ 0 is the applied strain (i.e. 25%).

sec.title: Thermal properties
sec.p:
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC, Mettler Toledo DSC823e, Zurich, Switzerland) was used to follow the thermal behavior of the dynamically cured 60/40 NR/PA-12 blends without and with various types of oils and plasticizers. The DSC characterization of pure rubbers (i.e. ADS, ENR-25, and ENR-50) and PA-12 was also carried out. The DSC was performed under dynamic conditions in nitrogen atmosphere with a rate of 20 ml/min. The sample weight of approximately 10 mg was first heated to 220°C, maintained at that temperature for 5 min to eliminate the thermal history. The sample was then quenched to −100°C with a cooling rate of 10°C/min followed by a second heating scan with the same rate until 220°C. The T g and T m of the samples were determined from the midpoint of the transition. Degree of crystallinity of PA-12 phase (X c) in the dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends was also determined from the cooling curve using the following equation: 4
X

where ▵H PA-12 is the apparent enthalpy of crystallization of PA-12, W PA-12 is the weight fraction of PA-12 in the blend, and ▵H PA-12, 100% is the extrapolated value of the enthalpy of 100% crystalline PA-12 (i.e. 233.5 J/g). 30

sec.title: Morphological characterization
sec.p: Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was used to characterize the morphological properties of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends with and without DOP. AFM images were captured at room temperature in a semicontact mode using Nanosurf easyScan 2 AFM (Liestal, Switzerland). The cantilever used was Nanosensors cantilever NCL-R Type (silicon probe) with a force constant (K) of 48 N/m and a dynamic frequency of 190 kHz. To obtain an ultrasmooth surface, the specimen was cut with a `glass knife at −100°C.

sec.title: Mixing torques and curing characteristics
sec.p: The mixing torque–time and temperature–time curves of 60/40 dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends with various types of NR (i.e. ADS, ENR-25, and ENR-50) without and with 30 phr of oil or plasticizer are shown in Figure 1. It can be seen that a slight increasing trend of the mixing torques at the first peak (i.e. at approximately 0.5 min) is observed due to the resistance of unmelted rubber compounds. A reduction in mixing torque is then observed because of the melting of rubber. Then, the second peak at a mixing time of approximately 2 min is observed due to the viscosities of blends after the incorporation of PA-12. A reduction in the torque is again observed because of the melting of PA-12 phase by mechanical shearing and frictional heat. The mixing torque of the blends is then abruptly increased (i.e. at approximately 2.5 min) due to the dynamic vulcanization of rubber phase. This led to a break-up of the temporary cocontinuous rubber phase into small rubber droplets dispersed in PA-12 matrix. Cross-linking of the rubber molecules also increases the viscosity of rubber phase and prevents coalescing of rubber particles. 31 Progressive reduction in the mixing torque is observed after dynamic vulcanization due to reduction in size of the dispersed rubber domains. Then, rather a constant mixing torque (i.e. a plateau zone) is observed at a mixing time of approximately 8 min. The mixing is continued until a total mixing time of 12 min to ensure the complete vulcanization of rubber phase in the blends. In Figure 1, it is also seen that the mixing temperature decreased after the incorporation of rubber compounds. The temperature thereafter slightly increased with increasing mixing time until a mixing time of 2 min when PA-12 is incorporated. A decreasing trend of mixing temperature is again observed due to the initial temperature of PA-12. The mixing temperature of blends is then abruptly increased with increasing the mixing time due to the exothermic cross-linking reaction of rubber phase and the shearing action during dynamic vulcanization. A constant mixing temperature is later observed after the mixing time of approximately 8 min.

caption.p: Relationship between mixing torque–time and temperature–time of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with various types of processing oils or plasticizer: (a) ADS/PA-12 blends, (b) ENR-25/PA-12 blends, and (c) ENR-50/PA-12 blends. NR, natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber.

sec.p: Influence of plasticizer and processing oils (i.e. DOP, paraffinic, and TDAE oils) on mixing torque–time and temperature–time curves of the dynamically cured ADS/PA-12, ENR-25/PA-12, and ENR-50/PA-12 blends is shown in Figure 1(a) to (c), respectively. It is seen that the oil-extended blends generated lower mixing torques and temperatures than those of the blends without oil. This may be attributed to lower frictional heat generated from lower viscosity of the oil-extended blends, which resulted in lower maximum torque, torque at the end of mixing, maximum temperature, and temperature at the end of mixing cycle, as summarized in Table 3. It is also seen that, in Figure 1(a) and Table 3, the dynamically cured ADS/PA-12 blend with DOP exhibited the highest maximum torque and temperature as well as the highest torque and temperature at the end of mixing cycle compared with the blends with paraffinic and TDAE oils, respectively. Furthermore, the blends with DOP reached the maximum torque (i.e. at the third peak) faster than those of the other types of the oil extended blends. Similar trend is observed in the dynamically cured ENR-25/PA-12 blends in Figure 1(b). This could be elucidated by the curing characteristics of ADS and ENR compounds, as the curing curves shown in Figure 2 and the summarized data is given in Table 4. It can be seen that the rubber compounds with DOP exhibited shorter scorch time (t S1) and cure time (t C90) and higher delta torques (▵S′) than those of the compounds with paraffinic and TDAE oils, respectively. This may be attributed to the difference in polarity and the reactivity of oil and plasticizer, which resulted in different curing characteristics, viscosities, and hence mixing torque, temperature curves, and curing reaction. This result agrees with decreasing scorch and cure times of NR compound mixed with palm oil fatty acid, which consists of functional groups with high polarity. 32 Also, the influence of oil on apparent shear viscosity, mixing torque, and curing reaction has been described elsewhere. 33

caption.p: Curing curves of rubber compounds without and with processing oils or plasticizer at 190°C based on (a) ADS, (b) ENR-25, and (c) ENR-50. ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber.
Mixing torques and mixing temperatures of dynamically cured 60/40 NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of processing oils or plasticizer

tr.td: Torque at the end of mixing (N m)
Temperature at the end of mixing (°C)

fn.p: ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; TPV, thermoplastic vulcanizate; DOP, dioctyl phthalate; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract; PO, paraffinic oil.

caption.p: Curing characteristics of ENR and ADS compounds without and with 30 phr of processing oils or plasticizer

fn.p: ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; DOP, dioctyl phthalate; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract.

sec.p: In Table 4, it is also seen that the cross-link density (i.e. torque difference, ▵S′) of TDAE extended rubber compounds is clearly lower than those of other types of the rubber compounds. This might be attributed to the disturbance of cross-linking reaction caused by the TDAE oil molecules. That is, the peroxy radicals of peroxide curing system could react with the aromatic carbon in the oil molecules. 34 This correlates well with the aniline point of the plasticizer and oils used, which can be ordered as follows: DOP (N/A) > PO (123°C) > TDAE oil (69°C). Higher aniline point indicates lower level of aromatic carbon atoms that causes less influence on cross-link reaction. Therefore, DOP contains higher effectiveness of free radicals to commence the curing reaction with shorter time to reach the maximum torque at the third peak of torque–time curves (Figure 1). Contrary result is observed in the dynamically cured ENR-50/PA-12 blends with TDAE oil, as shown in Figure 1(c). That is, the ENR-50/PA-12 blend with TDAE oil reached the maximum torque faster than that of the blend with PO. This may be attributed to larger difference in polarity between ENR-50, PA-12, and PO, which might delay the action of vulcanization.

sec.title: Rheological properties
sec.p: The influence of processing oil and plasticizer on rheological properties of dynamically cured 60/40 NR/PA-12 blends has been investigated. The results in terms of the relationship between apparent shear viscosity and apparent shear rate are shown in Figures 3 and 4. It can be seen that at a given shear rate, the shear viscosities of the blends without oil exhibit higher values than those of the oil-extended blends. Therefore, the later type of blend provided the ease of processing because of viscosity curves. That is, the oil-extended blends can be easily fabricated and processed by various processing methods in particular by plastic injection molding with lower injection pressure. Among three types of processing oils and plasticizers, the blends with PO exhibited the highest viscosity curve. On the other hand, the blends containing DOP provided intermediate curve while the blends with TDAE oil show the lowest curve. This may be attributed to different molecular structures, polarities, and compositions of oils and plasticizer, which resulted in a variation of solubility parameters (i.e. as shown in Table 6), viscosities, cross-link efficiency, and compatibility between rubber and PA-12 phases. Relationship between molecular structure and solubility parameter with viscosities, cross-link density, and compatibility of DOP, TDAE, and PO in NR compounds has been clearly described in our previous work. 35

caption.p: Relationship between apparent shear viscosity and apparent shear rate of dynamically cured (a) ADS/PA-12, (b) ENR-25/PA-12, and (c) ENR-50/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of various types of processing oils or plasticizer. PA-12, polyamide-12; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber.

Relationship between apparent shear viscosity and apparent shear rate of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends: (a) without oil, with 30 phr of (b) DOP, (c) paraffinic oil, and (d) TDAE oil. NR, natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12; DOP, dioctyl phthalate; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract.
TSSR results of dynamically cured 60/40 NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of processing oils or plasticizer

fn.p: TSSR, temperature scanning stress relaxation; NR, natural rubber; DOP, dioctyl phthalate; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12; TPV, thermoplastic vulcanizate; RI, rubber index.

caption.p: Hilderbrand solubility parameters of various types of rubber, processing oils, and plasticizer and the solvating (swelling) power (δ 1 − δ 2) of a polymer–oil medium

fn.p: DOP, dioctyl phthalate; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12; PO, paraffinic oil.

sec.p: In Figure 4, the ENR-50/PA-12 blend exhibited the highest viscosity curve followed by ENR-25/PA-12 and ADS/PA-12 blends. This result from the chemical interaction between epoxide groups in the ENR molecules and polar functional groups (i.e. –NH2, –COOH, –NH–CO–, respectively) in the PA-12 molecules, as described previously. 5,17 A proposed model of reaction between the polar functional groups of ENR and PA-12 to form NR-g-PA-12 located at the interface of ENR and PA-12 is shown in Figure 5. It is clear that strong linkage between ENR and PA-12 molecules (i.e., ENR-g-PA-12) which leads to stronger material and higher flow resistance in the molten state. This resulted in an increases in the shear viscosity. However, the blends with TDAE oil (Figure 4(d)) show lower viscosity curve for ENR-50/PA-12 blend than that of the ENR-25/PA-12 blend and ADS/PA-12 blend shows the lowest curve. This is attributed to lower cross-linking efficiency caused by the TDAE oil and hence yielded lower viscosity in all blend systems. The influence of TDAE oil is more pronounced in the ENR-50/PA-12 blends, which is in agreement with the lowest maximum torque and the torque at the end of mixing (Figure 1 and Table 3). An abrupt decrease in the torque difference is observed for TDAE oil extended ENR-50 compound (i.e. ▵S′TDAE = 0.64 dN m) compared with the ENR-50 compound with other types of oil or plasticizer (i.e. ▵S′PO = 1.25 dN m and ▵S′DOP = 1.39 dN m; Table 4). This may be due to increasing the level of interference in cross-linking reaction caused by the TDAE oil in the ENR-50/PA-12 blend.

caption.p: A proposed model for a reaction between epoxide groups in ENR molecules and polar functional groups to form ENR-g-PA-12 at the interface of ENR and PA-12 during dynamic curing of ENR/PA-12 blend. ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.

sec.title: Temperature scanning stress relaxation
sec.p: Figure 6 shows normalized force–temperature curves of dynamically cured ADS/PA-12, ENR-25/PA-12, and ENR-50/PA-12 blends without and with three different types of processing oils and plasticizer determined by TSSR measurement. It is seen that the addition of processing oils and plasticizer reduces the initial stress (σ 0). Furthermore, the blends with DOP exhibited higher force–temperature curve and initial stress (σ 0) than those of the blends without oil, followed by the blends with PO and TDAE oil, respectively. Blend with TDAE oil exhibits the sharpest decreasing trend of force with increasing testing temperature. Therefore, the blends with DOP provided higher integral values (i.e. the area underneath the normalized force-temperature curves) and hence higher RI than those of the others types of blends. This indicated an improvement of elastomeric behavior, 28 as results summarized in Table 5. It is seen that the incorporation of oil and plasticizer caused lowering value of T 90. This may be attributed to the diffusion of some amount of processing oil or plasticizer into the rubber and PA-12 phase. This caused lowering the degree of crystallization of PA-12 phase, which resulted in decreasing trend of thermal property in the oil extended blend. In Figure 6 and Table 5, an increase in initial stress (σ 0), T 10, T 50, T 90, integral value, and RI can be observed in the blends with ENR. This is attributed to the chemical interaction between ENR and PA-12 phases (Figure 5), which resulted in superior relaxation behavior and thermal properties. Furthermore, it is clear that the raise in epoxide content in ENR molecules caused a significant increase in the stress relaxation properties. Also, combination effects of chemical interaction between ENR and PA-12 phases and the addition of DOP led to an enhancement of stress relaxation properties. This accounts for greater relaxation behavior, thermal resistance (i.e. T 10, T 50, and T 90), and elastomeric nature (i.e. integral value and RI) compared with the blends with PO and TDAE oil. Moreover, the blends with DOP exhibited lower initial stress (σ 0) than that of the blend with PO, which implied lower stiffness and higher flexibility. However, the lowest initial stress (σ 0) is observed in the blends with TDAE oil. This is attributed to retardation of the cross-linking reaction due to aromatic content in the TDAE oil, as discussed earlier. Therefore, the initial stress (σ 0) of the blends can be ordered as follows: the blend without oil > the blend with PO > the blend with DOP > the blend with TDAE oil. This agrees well with the trend of shear viscosities of the blends in Figure 3.

caption.p: Normalized force–temperature curves of dynamically cured ADS/PA-12 (a), ENR-25/PA-12 (b), and ENR-50/PA-12 blends (c) without and with 30 phr of processing oils or plasticizer. ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.

sec.p: The TSSR results are correlated with the solvating (swelling) power (i.e. (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 ) according to the Hildebrand theory, 36 where δ 1 and δ 2 are the solubility parameters of polymer pairs (i.e. ADS, ENR, or PA-12) and plasticizer or processing oils (i.e. DOP, paraffinic, or TDAE oils), respectively. It has been well established that the solubility of polymer in solvent or oil is favored when (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 is minimized. That is, the solubility parameters of the two components are most closely matched. Table 6 shows the Hilderbrand solubility parameters of various types of rubber, PA-12, plasticizer, and processing oils with the solvating (swelling) power (δ 1 − δ 2)2 of rubber/oil and PA-12/oil mediums. It is seen that the (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 values of PA-12/DOP and rubber/DOP are lower than those of PA-12/TDAE oil, rubbers/TDAE oil, PA-12/PO, and rubber/PO. That is, the solubility parameters (δ) of various components are listed as follows: PA 37 -12 = 20.4 MPa1/2; ADS 38 = 16.5 MPa1/2; ENR-25 = 17.4 MPa1/2; and ENR 39 -50 = 18.2 MPa1/2. Therefore, the solubility parameters of ENR-25 and ENR-50 are close to DOP (δ = 18.2 MPa1/2) 35 than those of TDAE oil (δ = 16.4 MPa1/2) 38 and PO (δ = 14.5 MPa1/2), 33 respectively. Lower (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 resulted in higher possibility of oil to dissolve and distribute well into the rubber and amorphous phase of PA-12 and increases the ability of polymer chains to be more flexible, as a proposed model shown in Figure 7. This caused an enhancement of elastomeric properties and hence lowering the stiffness as well as an improvement of the stress relaxation properties. However, the blends with TDAE oil showed the lowest force–temperature curves, initial stress (σ 0), T 10, T 50, T 90, integral value, and RI. This is due to the TDAE oil caused retardation of cross-linking reaction, which resulted in poor elastomeric properties. The result is in good agreement with lower mixing torque (Figure 1) and lower shear viscosity (Figure 3) of the blends with TDAE oil.

caption.p: A proposed model representing the distribution of processing oil or plasticizer into dispersed rubber domains and PA-12 phases of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends. NR, natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows the relaxation spectra of dynamically cured ADS/PA-12, ENR-25/PA-12, and ENR-50/PA-12 blends with various types of processing oils and plasticizer. It can be seen that two different peaks can be observed in the spectra of dynamically cured blends. The first peaks at approximately 160°C revealed the degradation temperature of rubber phase during the TSSR test. It is clear that there is a significant difference between the blends with and without processing oil or plasticizer. That is, the peak has slightly shifted to lower temperature for all types of oil-extended blends (i.e. from approximately 160.5°C to 158–159°C for the ADS blend, from approximately 161.1°C to 158–160°C for the ENR-25 blend, and from approximately 162.5°C to 160–161°C for the ENR-50 blend). In addition, the second peaks are observed in a temperature range of 172–175°C, which corresponds to T m of the PA-12 phase. A slight shift has also been observed for the second peaks to lower temperature from approximately 174–175°C for the blends without oil to approximately 172–173.5°C for the oil-extended blends. The shift of temperatures is attributed to the lubricating effect of oil or plasticizer by enhancing the molecular flexibility. Furthermore, the blends with DOP show the second peaks at the lowest temperatures (i.e. lowest T m), while the blends with paraffinic and TDAE oils show the peaks at similar temperature. This is attributed to the higher solubility of DOP in PA-12 as evidenced by the lowest (δ 1 − δ 2)2 (Table 6). Consequently, lower degree of crystallinity and T m of PA-12 phase in the rubber/PA-12 blends with DOP is observed.

caption.p: TSSR relaxation spectra of dynamically cured ADS/PA-12 (a), ENR-25/PA-12 (b), and ENR-50/PA-12 (c) blends without and with 30 phr of various types of processing oils or plasticizer. TSSR, temperature scanning stress relaxation; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.

sec.p: In Figure 8, the TSSR relaxation spectra of the blends in a temperature range of 23–60°C are magnified in the upper left corner of the figure. It is seen that the peaks in a temperature range of 45.5–46.5°C are assigned to the glass transition relaxation (T g) of PA-12 phase in the dynamically cured rubber/PA-12 blends. It can be seen that the relaxation peak (i.e. T g of PA-12 phase) of the blends with DOP is not clearly observed. This might be the fact that the T g of PA-12 is shifted to lower temperature below 40°C due to strong compatibility between PA-12 and DOP. This is caused due to excess amount of DOP diffusions into the amorphous regions of PA-12 phase. Therefore, higher chain flexibility is observed by lowering the T g of PA-12 phase. However, the blends with paraffinic and TDAE oils do not show any significant effect on decreasing of the T g of PA-12 phase when compared with the blends without oil.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: Tensile strength and elongation at break of the dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends with various types of processing oils and plasticizer are shown in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. It is seen that the oil-extended blends exhibited lower tensile strength (Figure 9) but higher elongation at the breaks (Figure 10) when compared with the blend without oil. That is, the addition of processing oil or plasticizer caused decreasing of stiffness and strength properties of the blends. This is attributed to the increasing capability of rubber chains to move each other toward with more flexibility by increasing free volume between the entangled chains. Moreover, some amount of processing oil or plasticizer diffuse into the amorphous region of PA-12 phase. This is caused by an improvement in the softness and elasticity and hence increasing capability to extend or elongation at break. In addition, the blends with DOP apparently showed higher tensile strength than those of the blends with PO and TDAE oil, respectively. This corresponds to the magnitude of torque difference (▵S′) in the curing curves (Figure 2 and Table 4) which indicates the degree of cross-linking in rubber phase. The torque differences in rubber with various types of processing oil and plasticizer are ordered as follows: DOP > PO > TDAE oil. However, in the ENR-50/PA-12 blends with TDAE oil, a slightly higher tensile strength is observed when compared with the blend with PO. This is due to the incompatibility of the blend, which accounts for a large difference in polarity (i.e. difference in solubility parameter) between the polymer components and PO. Among the series of oil-extended blends, ENR-50/PA-12 blends exhibited higher tensile strength than those of ENR-25/PA-12 and ADS/PA-12 blends. This confirms the influence of chemical interaction between polar functional groups of ENR and PA-12 molecules, which leads to an increase in the strength properties (as a proposed model shown in Figure 5). Additionally, higher tensile strength is observed in the blend of ENR with higher epoxide content due to higher interfacial reaction between ENR-50 and PA-12. 17

caption.p: Tensile strength of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of various types of processing oils or plasticizer. NR, natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.
Elongation at the break of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of various types of processing oils or plasticizer. NR, natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.

sec.p: In Figure 10, the magnitude of the elongation at break of the oil-extended NR/PA-12 blends are correlated with the (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 (Table 6). That is, the blends with DOP (i.e. with the lowest (δ 1 − δ 2)2) exhibited higher elongation at break than those of the blends with TDAE and POs, respectively. This is attributed to the greater compatibilizing effect of PA-12, rubber, and DOP, as indicated by the lowest (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 . This led to better distribution of the oil into rubber and PA-12 phases. Also, the disruption of crystalline region in PA-12 by dissolving in oil and plasticizing or swelling effect of the rubber phase might occur. As a consequence, higher amorphous content in the PA-12 phase and softer rubber domains are accounted for higher elongation at break.

Figure 11 illustrates the indentation hardness of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with processing oil or plasticizer. As expected, the addition of processing oil or plasticizer decreases the hardness when compared with the blends without oil. To compare the blends with two types of processing oils and plasticizer, the hardness can be ordered as follows: DOP > PO > TDAE oil. This again corresponds to the trend of torque difference (▵S′) in the curing curves (Figure 2 and Table 4) and shear viscosities (Figure 3). Among different types of rubber used, the ENR/PA-12 blends exhibited superior tensile and hardness properties. This is due to the formation of in situ graft copolymerization of ENR and PA-12 molecules at the interface, as described in Figure 5. This resulted in higher tensile strength (Figure 9), elongation at break (Figure 10), and hardness (Figure 11). However, the ENR-50/PA-12 blends exhibited lower elongation at break than those of the ENR-25/PA-12 blends as a result of strong interfacial adhesion between the phases, which restrict the chain mobility.

caption.p: Indentation hardness (shore D) of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with 30 phr of various types of processing oils or plasticizer. NR, natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12.

sec.title: Thermal properties
sec.p: DSC thermograms of the dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with various types of processing oils or plasticizer at a loading level of 30 phr are shown in Figure 12. Various thermal properties based on the DSC thermograms are summarized in Table 7. It can be seen that the T g of PA-12 phase is not able to be determined by DSC technique due to a very small change in the heat capacity (i.e. ▵Cp) of the amorphous phase of PA-12, which needs to transition the glassy amorphous region to rubbery states. That is, the DSC may not be sensitive to detect the T g of a polymer with highly crystalline. 40 In Table 7, it is clearly seen that the thermal properties of rubber/PA-12 blends are influenced by the addition of processing oil. That is, the incorporation of processing oil or plasticizer decreases the T g of NR phase and also crystallization temperature (T c) and T m of PA-12 phase in the blend. The degree of crystallinity (X c) of PA-12 phase is also slightly decreased by dissolving some crystalline regions in oil or plasticizer with increasing the free volume in PA-12 matrix, which becomes amorphous phase. This observation is in agreement with the distribution of oil in various blend systems, including NR/HDPE, 7 NR/PP, 18 ENR/HDPE, 25 PP/EPDM, and PP/SEBS blends. 26 In Table 7, the T g value of rubber phase in ENR-25/PA-12 blend is ordered in accordance with the T g of processing oil and plasticizer (i.e. −48°C for TDAE oil, 41 −58°C for PO 42 , and −85°C for DOP, 43 respectively). That is, the ENR-25 phase of the blend with DOP exhibited the lowest T g, followed by the T g of ENR-25 phase of the blend with PO and TDAE oil, respectively (Table 7). On the other hand, the ADS phase in the blend with DOP and PO exhibited similar values of T g while the highest T g value is observed in the ADS phase of the blend with TDAE oil. Furthermore, it is seen that the ENR-50 phase in the blend with DOP exhibited the lowest T g, while the ENR-50 phase in the blend with PO shows higher T g compared with the rubber phase in the blend with the TDAE oil. This is due to the incompatibility between ENR-50 and PO, which caused excess amount of oil to form a separate oil phase or oil domain. 18 Therefore, chain flexibility of the rubber molecules is restricted by the presence of these domains. However, the lower values of (δ 1−δ 2)2 in ENR-50 blend with DOP (Table 6) lead to a higher capability of DOP to diffuse into the dispersed vulcanized rubber domains. Therefore, the oil-swollen rubber particles with greater chain flexibility and lower T g have been observed. Additionally, it is found that the rubber/PA-12 blends with DOP provided lower values of T m and Xc than those of the blend with TDAE oil as a result of greater amount of DOP diffused into the PA-12 phase. However, the ENR/PA-12 blends with PO show smaller change in T g of the rubber phase, especially in the ENR-50/PA-12 blend, but higher T c, T m, and Xc of PA-12 are observed compared with the ENR/PA-12 blends with other types of oils (Table 7). This can be ascribed in terms of a large difference in the solubility parameters among ENRs, PA-12, and PO with higher (δ 1 − δ 2) 2 of polymer–PO medium (Table 6). This leads to a formation of large PO droplets in PA-12 matrix as a proposed model shown in Figure 7(d). This is presumably caused by a reduction in impediment in the crystalline growth of PA-12 and hence the higher degree of crystallization of PA-12. Considering the influence on types of rubber, it can be seen that the Xc is slightly decreased in the blends with ENR. Furthermore, higher epoxide content lowers the Xc because of the chemical interaction between ENR and PA-12 molecules at the interface, which restricted the chain movement of PA-12 molecules, as described in our previous work. 5 This is in agreement with the crystallization behavior of dynamically cured EPDM/nylon copolymer blend 15 and PA-6/polyolefin blend compatibilized with ENR. 44

caption.p: DSC thermograms of dynamically cured 60/40 rubber/PA-12 blends without and with various types of processing oils. DSC, Differential scanning calorimetry; PA-12, polyamide-12.

Glass transition temperatures (T g) of ADS and ENRs phases, degree of crystallization (X c), crystallization temperatures (T c), and crystalline melting temperatures (T m) of PA-12 phase of dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends without and with different types of processing oils and plasticizer at a loading level of 30 phr

fn.p: ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; PA-12, polyamide-12; DOP, dioctyl phthalate; PO, paraffinic oil; TDAE, treated distillate aromatic extract.

sec.title: Morphological properties
sec.p: Figure 13 shows the AFM images of the dynamically cured NR/PA-12 blends with different types of rubber with and without DOP. In the AFM images, it is clear that the lighter domains represent the soft phase of cross-linked rubber particles dispersed in the darker hard matrix of PA-12 matrix. It is seen that the dynamically cured ENR-50/PA-12 blends exhibited smaller vulcanized rubber domains than those of the ENR-25/PA-12 and ADS/PA-12 blends, respectively. This is due to the higher level of in situ formation of ENR-g-PA at the interface of ENR-50 and PA-12 molecules, which is caused by higher compatibilizing effect between ENR-50 and PA-12 phases and generated smaller vulcanized rubber domains with finely dispersed in PA-12 matrix. In addition, the increasing level of epoxide groups in ENR molecules reduces the size of vulcanized rubber domains due to higher chemical interaction. It is also seen that the incorporation of DOP into the blend leads into the formation of larger vulcanized rubber domains. This is attributed to the distribution of DOP into the dispersed vulcanized rubber domains which becomes oil-swollen rubber particles. This correlates well with improvement in stress relaxation behavior (Figure 6), higher elongation at break (Figure 10), lower tensile strength (Figure 9), hardness (Figure 11), and T g of the rubber phase (Table 7). A lower melt viscosity is also observed in the blends with DOP compared with the blends without oil (Figure 1). Diffusion of plasticizer or oil into the vulcanizing rubber phase is responsible for the reduction in shear and elongational viscosities during blending operation. This might be a reason for lowering the capability to break up of the cocontinuous vulcanizing rubber phase into smaller rubber domains. Therefore, larger vulcanized rubber domains are observed in the DOP-extended blend.

caption.p: AFM images of dynamically cured rubber/PA-12 blends: (a) ADS/PA-12 without oil, (b) ENR-25/PA-12 without oil, (c) ENR-50/PA-12 without oil, (d) ADS/PA-12 with DOP, (e) ENR-25/PA-12 with DOP, and (f) ENR-50/PA-12 with DOP. AFM, atomic force microscopy; PA-12, polyamide-12; ADS, air dried sheet; ENR, epoxidized natural rubber; DOP, dioctyl phthalate.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Dynamically peroxide cured 60/40 NR/PA-12 blends with three different types of NR without and with 30 phr of processing oils or plasticizer (i.e. TDAE oil, PO, and DOP) were prepared by melt-mixing process. It was found that the incorporation of oil or plasticizer has improved the processability and elastic behavior as indicated by lowering mixing torque and shear viscosity but decreasing tensile strength and hardness. The main factors influenced on the properties of oil-extended blends are chemical interaction between ENR and PA-12 phases, compatibility, or solubility among NR, PA-12, and oil (i.e. based on their solubility parameters) and the cross-link efficiency. A formation of ENR-g-PA-12 at the interface caused improvement of compatibility of the blend. This is obviously the reason for higher mixing torque, shear viscosity, stress relaxation, and mechanical properties of the blends. Furthermore, it was found that the NR/PA-12 blends with DOP gave superior stress relaxation behavior and mechanical properties compared with other types of oil and plasticizer. This is due to small difference in the solubility parameter of the DOP compared with the solubility parameters of the polymer pairs. Moreover, lower cross-link efficiency of the rubber compounds with aromatic carbon content in the oil was observed. This caused inferior properties of the peroxide cured NR/PA-12 blends. Incorporation of DOP into the blend also caused lowering T g of ENR phase to gather with T m and Xc of the PA-12 phase. This is attributed to the diffusion of DOP into both vulcanized ENR particles and PA-12 phase, which resulted in greater flexibility of ENR chains. Also, dissolving of some crystalline regions in PA-12 matix occurred, which thereafter transformed to the amorphous region. Furthermore, oil-swollen rubber domains were observed due to the diffusion of oil or plasticizer into the rubber phase.

fn.p: This work was supported by Thailand Research Fund through the Royal Golden Jubilee PhD Program (grant no. PHD/0138/2548) and the DAAD-TRF Project Based Personnel Exchange Programme (PPP 2008) for financial support. This work was also partly supported by the Higher Education Research Promotion and National Research University Project of Thailand, Office of the Higher Education Commission.
